prompt.p: A patient presents with polyuria and polydipsia with particular thirst for cold water. Very dilute urine is produced with a low specific gravity, otherwise urine dipstick is normal. Blood tests reveal a high plasma sodium of 150 mmol/l (normal 135â€“145 mmol/l). There is no change in urine output on fluid restriction; however, urine output is reduced by desmopressin.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

modalFeedback.p: Option A is Correct. See Targeted Learning for further information.
Option B is Incorrect. Glucose can induce an osmotic diuresis and cause polyuria. Normal blood and urinary glucose would make this diagnosis unlikely.

Option C is Incorrect. This is extremely rare as a cause of hypernatraemia and would require massive salt ingestion. This will usually correct spontaneously if renal function is normal as sodium will be rapidly excreted in the urine.

Option D is Incorrect. In nephrogenic diabetes the renal proximal tubules are resistant to the effects of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). Plasma ADH is at maximal levels. Hence administering desmopressin (synthetic ADH) would not change urine output.

Option E is Incorrect. This can cause syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) which causes hyponatraemia. SIADH would not cause polyuria, and a water deprivation test would not improve this symptom.
